fields.name: C4.5 Tree Learner
fields.description: C4.5 learner by Ross Quinlan, this widget provides a graphical interface to the well-known Quinlan’s C4.5 algorithm for construction of classification tree.

fields.name: C4.5 Tree Learner
fields.description: The C4.5 learning algorithm.

fields.name: CN2 Rule Learner
fields.description: Use this widget to learn a set of if-then rules from data. The algorithm is based on CN2 algorithm.

fields.name: CN2 Rule Learner
fields.description: The CN2 Rule learning algorithm.

fields.name: Classification Tree
fields.description: Classification Tree Learner.

fields.name: Classification Tree Learner
fields.description: The classification tree learning algorithm.

fields.name: Logistic Regression
fields.description: Logistic regression is a statistical classification method that fits data to a logistic function. A logistic regression classification model stores estimated values of regression coefficients and their significances, and uses them to predict classes and class probabilities.

fields.name: Logistic Regresion Learner
fields.description: The logistic regression learning algorithm.

fields.name: Lookup Learner
fields.description: Lookup classifiers predict classes by looking into stored lists of cases. A learner sorts the data instances and merges those with the same feature values.

fields.name: Lookup Learner
fields.description: Lookup learning algorithm.

fields.name: Majority Learner
fields.description: A Learner that returns the majority class, disregarding the example’s attributes. Accuracy of classifiers is often compared with the “default accuracy”, that is, the accuracy of a classifier which classifies all instances to the majority class. The training of such classifier consists of computing the class distribution and its modus. This “learning algorithm” will most often be used as a baseline, that is, to determine if some other learning algorithm provides any information about the class.

fields.name: Majority Learner
fields.description: The “learning” algorithm.

fields.name: Naive Bayes
fields.description: A Naive Bayes classifier is a probabilistic classifier that estimates conditional probabilities of the dependant variable from training data and uses them for classification of new data instances. The algorithm is very fast for discrete features, but runs slower for continuous features.

fields.name: Bayes Learner
fields.description: The naive Bayesian learning algorithm.

fields.name: Random Forest
fields.description: Random forest is a classification technique that, given the set of class-labeled data, builds a set of classification trees. Each tree is developed from a bootstrap sample from the training data. When developing individual trees, an arbitrary subset of attributes is drawn (hence the term “random”) from which the best attribute for the split is selected. The classification is based on the majority vote from individually developed tree classifiers in the forest.

fields.name: Number of decision trees
fields.description: tells the algorithm how many classification trees will be included in the forest.

fields.name: Random Forest Learner
fields.description: The random forest learning algorithm.

fields.name: Rule Induction
fields.description: A base rule induction learner. The algorithm follows separate-and-conquer strategy, which has its origins in the AQ family of algorithms (Fuernkranz J.; Separate-and-Conquer Rule Learning, Artificial Intelligence Review 13, 3-54, 1999). Such algorithms search for the optimal rule for the current training set, remove the covered training instances (separate) and repeat the process (conquer) on the remaining data.

fields.name: Rule Learner
fields.description: Rule Learner algorithm.

fields.name: Support Vector Machine
fields.description: Support vector machine learner.

fields.name: Support Vector Machine Learner
fields.description: The support vector machine learning algorithm.

fields.name: Support Vector Machine Easy
fields.description: Learning algorithm which helps with the data normalization and parameter tuning.

fields.name: Support Vector Machine Easy Learner
fields.description: SVM Easy learning algorithm.

fields.name: k-Nearest Neighbours
fields.description: The nearest neighbors algorithm is one of the most basic, lazy machine learning algorithms. The learner only stores the training data, and the classifier makes predictions based on the instances most similar to the data instance being classified.

fields.name: kNN Learner
fields.description: The kNN learning algorithm.

fields.name: Attribute distance
fields.description: Computes the distances between the attributes in the data sets. Don’t confuse it with a similar widget for computing the distances between examples.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: A list of examples

fields.name: Measures for attributes
fields.description: The two kinds of attributes (discrete and continuous) have different measures of distance.

fields.name: Distance matrix
fields.description: A matrix of attribute distances.

fields.name: Example Distance
fields.description: Computes the distances between the examples in the data set.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: A list of examples

fields.name: Distance Metrics
fields.description: The available Distance Metrics definitions are Euclidean, Manhattan, Hammming and Relief. Besides, of course, different formal definitions, the measures also differ in how correctly they treat unknown values. Manhattan and Hamming distance do not excel in this respect; Relief distance is similar to Manhattan, but with a more correct treatment for discrete attributes.

fields.name: Distance matrix
fields.description: A matrix of example distances

fields.name: Hierarchical clustering
fields.description: The widget computes hierarchical clustering of arbitrary types of objects from the matrix of distances between them and shows the corresponding diagram. If the distances apply to examples, the widget offers some special functionality (adding cluster indices, outputting examples...).

fields.name: Distance Matrix
fields.description: A matrix of distances between items being clustered

fields.name: Linkage
fields.description: The widget supports three kinds of linkages. In Single linkage clustering, the distance between two clusters is defined as the distance between the closest elements of the two clusters. Average linkage clustering computes the average distance between elements of the two clusters, and Complete linkage defines the distance between two clusters as the distance between their most distant elements.

fields.name: Centroids
fields.description: A list of cluster centroids

fields.name: Selected examples
fields.description: A list of selected examples; applicable only when the input matrix refers to distances between examples

fields.name: Unselected examples
fields.description: A list of unselected examples

fields.name: Classifier
fields.description: Classifier to be applied

fields.name: Evaluation Results
fields.description: Results of classifiers’ tests on data.

fields.name: Brier Score
fields.description: Computes the Brier's score, defined as the average (over test examples) of sumx(t(x)-p(x))^2, where x is a class, t(x) is 1 for the correct class and 0 for the others, and p(x) is the probability that the classifier assigned to the class x.

fields.name: Classification Accuracy
fields.description: Computes classification accuracy, i.e. percentage of matches between predicted and actual class. The function returns a list of classification accuracies of all classifiers tested. If reportSE is set to true, the list will contain tuples with accuracies and standard errors.

fields.name: Evaluation Results
fields.description: Evaluation results

fields.name: Confusion Matrix
fields.description: Confusion Matrix gives the number/proportion of examples from one class classified in to another (or same) class. Besides that, selecting elements of the matrix feeds the corresponding examples onto the output signal. This way, one can observe which specific examples were misclassified in a certain way.

fields.name: Evaluation Results
fields.description: Evaluation results

fields.name: Cutoff
fields.description: We can also add the keyword argument cutoff (e.g. confusionMatrices(results, cutoff=0.3); if we do, confusionMatrices will disregard the classifiers' class predictions and observe the predicted probabilities, and consider the prediction "positive" if the predicted probability of the positive class is higher than the cutoff.

fields.name: Class Index
fields.description: Index of class value for which the confusion matrices are to be computed.

fields.name: Confusion Matrix Computations
fields.description: With the confusion matrix defined in terms of positive and negative classes, you can also compute the sensitivity [TP/(TP+FN)], specificity [TN/(TN+FP)], positive predictive value [TP/(TP+FP)] and negative predictive value [TN/(TN+FN)]. In information retrieval, positive predictive value is called precision (the ratio of the number of relevant records retrieved to the total number of irrelevant and relevant records retrieved), and sensitivity is called recall (the ratio of the number of relevant records retrieved to the total number of relevant records in the database). The harmonic mean of precision and recall is called an F-measure, where, depending on the ratio of the weight between precision and recall is implemented as F1 [2*precision*recall/(precision+recall)] or, for a general case, Falpha [(1+alpha)*precision*recall / (alpha*precision + recall)].

fields.name: Correct Class Average Probability
fields.description: Computes the average probability assigned to the correct class.

fields.name: Evaluation Results
fields.description: Evaluation results

fields.name: Information Score
fields.description: Computes the information score as defined by Kononenko and Bratko (1991).

fields.name: Evaluation Results
fields.description: Evaluation results

fields.name: Mean Absolute Error
fields.description: One of the several alternative measures to be used to evaluate the success of numeric prediction.

fields.name: Mean Squared Error
fields.description: One of the several alternative measures to be used to evaluate the success of numeric prediction.

fields.name: R-squared
fields.description: One of the several alternative measures to be used to evaluate the success of numeric prediction.

fields.name: Relative Squared Error
fields.description: One of the several alternative measures to be used to evaluate the success of numeric prediction.

fields.name: Root Mean-squared Error
fields.description: One of the several alternative measures to be used to evaluate the success of numeric prediction.

fields.name: Root Relative Squared Error
fields.description: One of the several alternative measures to be used to evaluate the success of numeric prediction.

fields.name: Cross Validation
fields.description: Returns the object stored in results, which essentially stores the probabilities and class values of the instances that were used as test cases.

fields.name: Leave One Out
fields.description: Performs a leave-one-out experiment with the given list of learners and examples. This is equivalent to performing len(examples)-fold cross validation. Function accepts additional keyword arguments for preprocessing, storing classifiers and verbose output.

fields.name: Proportion Test
fields.description: Splits the data with a number of examples in the learning and the rest in the testing set. The test is repeated for a given number of times (default 10). Division is stratified by default. Function also accepts keyword arguments for randomization and storing classifiers.

fields.name: ARFF string to Orange Data Table
Add Class Noise
fields.description: Adds class noise to a specified percentage of data instances.

fields.name: Alter table
fields.description: Alter individual values in an Orange Data Table.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: Original table

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: Altered table

fields.name: Dataset Discretization
fields.description: Discretizes continuous attrbutes from input data set.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: Attribute-valued data set.

fields.name: Discretizators
fields.description: Example-based automatic discretization is in essence similar to learning: given a set of examples, discretization method proposes a list of suitable intervals to cut the attribute's values into. For this reason, Orange structures for discretization resemble its structures for learning. Objects derived from orange.Discretization play a role of "learner" that, upon observing the examples, construct an orange.Discretizer whose role is to convert continuous values into discrete according to the rule found by Discretization.

fields.name: Number of intervals
fields.description: Number of intervals is user-defined.

fields.name: Cut-off points
fields.description: Comma separated cut-off points

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: Attribute-valued data set composed from instances from input data set that match user-defined condition.

fields.name: Load Dataset to Orange Data Table
Orange Data Table
fields.description: Attribute-valued data set read from the input file.

fields.name: Orange Data Table to ARFF File
Orange Data Table to ARFF String
fields.description: Transforms an orange data table to an arff string.

fields.name: Orange Data Table to CSV File
Orange Data Table to TAB File
Select Attributes
fields.description: Select Attributes widget is used to manually compose your data domain, that is, to decide which attributes will be used and how. Orange distinguishes between ordinary attributes, an (optional) class attributes and meta attributes.

fields.name: Orange Data tTble
fields.description: Attribute-valued data set.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: Modified data set, composed using the domain specification constructed using the widget.

fields.name: Select Data
fields.description: This widget allows the user to select a subset of the data from the input data set based on the condition defined over a set of data’s attributes. Data instances that match the selection rule are placed on the output channel.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: Attribute-valued data set.

fields.name: Matching Data
fields.description: Attribute-valued data set composed from instances from input data set that match user-defined condition.

fields.name: Split dataset
fields.description: Splits a dataset to a train and test dataset.

fields.name: Orange Data Table
fields.description: A dataset that will be split into two parts

fields.name: Split factor
fields.description: A number between 0 and 1 that determines the sizes of the two datasets

fields.name: Train data
fields.description: Train data

fields.name: Test data
fields.description: Test data

fields.name: Table Viewer
fields.description: Widget presents Orange Data Table in a spreadsheet format. Widget supports sorting by attribute values (click on the attribute name in the header row).

fields.name: Tree Visualization
fields.description: Used to visually represent classification trees.

fields.name: UCI Dataset to Orange Data Table
Filter ReliefF
fields.description: Takes the data set data and a measure for score of attributes measure. Repeats the process of estimating attributes and removing the worst attribute if its measure is lower than margin. Stops when no attribute score is below this margin. The default for measure is relief(k=20, m=50), and margin defaults to 0.0.

fields.name: Score estimation (Relief)
fields.description: Assesses features’ ability to distinguish between very similar instances from different classes. This scoring method was first developed by Kira and Rendell and then improved by Kononenko.

fields.name: Select Attributes Above Threshold
fields.description: Constructs and returns a new data set that includes a class and attributes from the list returned by function attMeasure that have the score above or equal to a specified threshold. data is used to pass an original data set. Parameter threshold is optional and defaults to 0.0.

fields.name: Select best N attributes
fields.description: Constructs and returns a new data set that includes a class and only N best attributes from a list scores. data is used to pass an original data set.
